title: 150 MCQ Questions on Fundamental Rights in Indian Constitution
description: Comprehensive collection of multiple choice questions covering all 6 fundamental rights with detailed explanations and landmark cases

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the core principle of Article 14 of the Indian Constitution?

options.A: Equal protection of law to all persons regardless of their citizenship

questions.explanation: Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons within the territory of India. The landmark case of State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar (1952) established that this article applies to all persons, not just citizens. The Supreme Court in this case held that the West Bengal Special Courts Act conferred arbitrary powers for classification without clear guidelines, violating the principle of equal protection of law.
questions.landmark_case: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar, 1952

questions.question: The 'classification test' for Article 14 was established in which landmark case?

options.A: E.P. Royappa v. State of Tamil Nadu
options.B: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Justice Tendolkar
options.C: Magan Lal Chaggan Lal v. Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay
options.D: Indra Sawhney v. Union of India

questions.explanation: The 'classification test' was established by Justice Tendolkar in Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Justice Tendolkar (1958). This test permits differential classification of subjects by the State, provided it is founded on 'intelligible differentia' (objects within the class are clearly distinguishable from those outside) and has a 'rational nexus' with the objective sought to be achieved by the classification.
questions.landmark_case: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Justice Tendolkar, 1958

questions.question: Which case established the 'arbitrariness test' for Article 14 of the Indian Constitution?

options.A: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
options.B: E.P. Royappa v. State of Tamil Nadu
options.C: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Justice Tendolkar
options.D: Magan Lal Chaggan Lal v. Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay

questions.explanation: The 'arbitrariness test' was established by Justice Bhagwati in E.P. Royappa v. State of Tamil Nadu (1974). This case introduced the doctrine that Article 14 includes a guarantee against arbitrariness in State action. This test has been frequently used to declare State actions ultra vires Article 14, ensuring that government actions must be rational and non-arbitrary.
questions.landmark_case: E.P. Royappa v. State of Tamil Nadu, 1974

questions.question: The 'triumvirate' test linking Articles 14, 19, and 21 was established in which case?

options.A: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
options.B: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
options.D: S.R. Bommai v. Union of India

questions.explanation: The 'triumvirate' test was established in Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978). A seven-Judge Bench considered the relationship between Articles 14, 19, and 21, establishing that any law interfering with personal liberty must satisfy a triple test: (1) prescribe a procedure, (2) withstand Article 19's fundamental rights, and (3) be tested against Article 14. The procedure must be right, just, fair, non-arbitrary, fanciful or oppressive.
questions.landmark_case: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India, 1978

questions.question: In the landmark case Indra Sawhney v. Union of India, the Supreme Court held that:

options.A: Reservation in government jobs is unconstitutional
options.B: Article 16(4) is a facet of Article 14 and permits reasonable reservations
options.C: No reservations can be made in private sector jobs
options.D: Only economic backwardness can be a ground for reservation

questions.explanation: In Indra Sawhney v. Union of India (1993), the Supreme Court held that Article 16(1) is a facet of Article 14. Both articles permit reasonable classification, which may include reservation. The primary aim of both Article 14 and 16 is equality and equality of opportunity, and Article 16(4) is a means to achieve this. The court established that reservations should not exceed 50% and identified the 'creamy layer' concept to exclude advanced sections from reservations.
questions.landmark_case: Indra Sawhney v. Union of India, 1993

questions.question: Which case declared the practice of triple talaq unconstitutional under Article 14?

options.A: Shayara Bano v. Union of India
options.C: Joseph Shine v. Union of India
options.D: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India

questions.explanation: In Shayara Bano v. Union of India (2017), a 5-Judge Bench declared instantaneous triple talaq (Talaq-ul-biddat) unconstitutional. The court stated that the fundamental right to equality under Article 14 encompasses gender equality, equity, and justice. Conferring social status based on patriarchal values or male mercy is incompatible with the letter and spirit of Articles 14 and 15.
questions.landmark_case: Shayara Bano v. Union of India, 2017

questions.question: The case that recognized the rights of transgender persons under Article 14 was:

options.A: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India
options.B: National Legal Service Authority (NALSA) v. Union of India
options.C: Joseph Shine v. Union of India
options.D: Shayara Bano v. Union of India

questions.explanation: In National Legal Service Authority (NALSA) v. Union of India (2014), the Supreme Court held that the right to equality under Article 14 is framed in gender-neutral terms ('all persons') and thus extends to transgender persons. This case recognized the rights of the third gender to equality and protection against discrimination, ensuring that the Constitution protects all persons regardless of their gender identity.
questions.landmark_case: National Legal Service Authority (NALSA) v. Union of India, 2014

questions.question: Which case decriminalized consensual same-sex relations?

options.A: Joseph Shine v. Union of India
options.B: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India
options.D: Shayara Bano v. Union of India

questions.explanation: In Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India (2018), a five-judge Bench considered the constitutionality of Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code, specifically concerning same-sex relations between consenting adults. The Bench unanimously struck down Section 377 IPC to the extent it criminalized consensual same-sex relations, holding it violative of the right to equality under Article 14, which equally applies to same-sex couples.
questions.landmark_case: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India, 2018

questions.question: Which case decriminalized adultery under Article 14?

options.A: Shayara Bano v. Union of India
options.B: Joseph Shine v. Union of India
options.C: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India

questions.explanation: In Joseph Shine v. Union of India (2018), a five-judge Bench examined the constitutionality of Section 497 of the Indian Penal Code (adultery) and Section 198 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The Bench unanimously struck down Section 497 IPC, thereby decriminalizing adultery, on grounds that it violates Articles 14, 15, and 21. The court declared it an archaic and paternalistic law infringing upon a woman's autonomy and dignity.
questions.landmark_case: Joseph Shine v. Union of India, 2018

questions.question: The case that dealt with the Sabarimala Temple entry restriction was:

options.A: Shayara Bano v. Union of India
options.B: Indian Young Lawyers' Association v. State of Kerala
options.C: Joseph Shine v. Union of India
options.D: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India

questions.explanation: In Indian Young Lawyers' Association v. State of Kerala (2018), the Supreme Court by a 4:1 majority declared the Sabarimala Temple's custom prohibiting women of 'menstruating years' from entering the temple premises unconstitutional. The decision was based on equality principles under Article 14, emphasizing that constitutional rights cannot be superseded by religious customs that violate gender equality.
questions.landmark_case: Indian Young Lawyers' Association v. State of Kerala, 2018

questions.question: Which case challenged employment discrimination based on pregnancy and marriage?

options.D: Harsh Mander v. Union of India

questions.explanation: In Air India v. Nargesh Meerza (1978), the Supreme Court struck down Air India's rules for female flight attendants which required retirement upon reaching 35 years of age, marriage, or first pregnancy - rules not applicable to male attendants. The Court held these rules constituted official arbitrariness and hostile discrimination, violating Article 14's guarantee of equality.
questions.landmark_case: Air India v. Nargesh Meerza, 1978

questions.question: Which case dealt with the right against workplace sexual harassment?

options.D: Harsh Mander v. Union of India

questions.explanation: In Visakha v. State of Rajasthan (1997), the Supreme Court held that sexual harassment violates women's fundamental right to gender equality under Article 14 and the right to life under Article 21. Even without an express constitutional provision, the right against sexual harassment at the workplace is implicit in these fundamental rights. The court established guidelines for prevention of sexual harassment, which later formed the basis for the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act.
questions.landmark_case: Visakha v. State of Rajasthan, 1997

questions.question: Which case decriminalized begging as a violation of Article 14?

options.C: Harsh Mander v. Union of India
options.D: Nar Gayatan v. Union of India

questions.explanation: In Harsh Mander v. Union of India (2018), the Delhi High Court decriminalized begging by challenging the Bombay Prevention of Begging Act, 1959, which criminalized various forms of begging. The court stated that begging is not a disease and criminalizing it is a direct attack on the fundamental rights of the poorest to access basic necessities like food and shelter, violating Article 14's guarantee of equality.
questions.landmark_case: Harsh Mander v. Union of India, 2018

questions.question: Which clause of Article 15 allows special provisions for women and children?
questions.explanation: Article 15(3) explicitly states that 'Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any special provision for women and children.' This clause enables the State to enact gender-specific laws and policies, such as reserved seats for women in local bodies, maternity benefits, and other protective legislation that would otherwise appear to discriminate on the basis of sex.
questions.landmark_case: General Constitutional Provision

questions.question: Which article contains provisions for reservation in public employment?
questions.explanation: Article 16 specifically deals with 'Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment.' Article 16(4) allows the State to make provision for reservation of appointments or posts in favor of any backward class of citizens which, in the opinion of the State, is not adequately represented in the services under the State. This is the constitutional basis for reservations in government jobs and promotions.
questions.landmark_case: General Constitutional Provision

questions.question: Article 17 of the Indian Constitution deals with:
questions.explanation: Article 17 states that 'Untouchability' is abolished and its practice in any form is forbidden. The enforcement of any disability arising out of 'Untouchability' shall be an offence punishable in accordance with law. This article makes untouchability a punishable offense and aims to eliminate the social evil that has been prevalent in Indian society for centuries.
questions.landmark_case: General Constitutional Provision

questions.question: Which of the following titles can still be conferred by the State according to Article 18?
questions.explanation: Article 18(1) states that 'No title, not being a military or academic distinction, shall be conferred by the State.' This means that military and academic distinctions are exceptions to the general prohibition on conferring titles. Military decorations like Param Vir Chakra and academic distinctions like honorary doctorates are still permitted.
questions.landmark_case: General Constitutional Provision

questions.question: The term 'person' in Article 14 includes:

options.C: Both citizens and non-citizens, including legal persons

questions.explanation: Article 14 guarantees equality before the law or equal protection of the laws to 'any person' within the territory of India. This includes both citizens and non-citizens (foreign nationals, stateless persons) as well as legal persons (corporations, associations). The use of 'person' makes Article 14 comprehensive and ensures protection to all individuals within India's jurisdiction.
questions.landmark_case: General Constitutional Provision

questions.question: The 'equal protection of the laws' means:

options.B: Different treatment based on reasonable classification

questions.explanation: The 'equal protection of the laws' does not mean identical treatment for all persons. It means that persons similarly situated must be treated similarly, and persons in different circumstances may be treated differently if there is a reasonable classification. This is the basis of the classification test established in Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Justice Tendolkar (1958).
questions.landmark_case: General Constitutional Interpretation

questions.question: Article 14 is violated when:

options.B: The State acts arbitrarily without any rational basis

questions.explanation: Article 14 is violated when the State acts in an arbitrary manner without any rational basis for distinction. The Supreme Court in E.P. Royappa v. State of Tamil Nadu (1974) established the arbitrariness test, holding that Article 14 is a guarantee against arbitrary State action. Any action that is fanciful, whimsical, or capricious violates Article 14.
questions.landmark_case: E.P. Royappa v. State of Tamil Nadu, 1974

questions.question: Article 16(4A) allows reservation in:
questions.explanation: Article 16(4A) states that 'Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any provision for reservation in matters of promotion, with consequential seniority, to any class or classes of posts in the services under the State in favour of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes which, in the opinion of the State, are not adequately represented in the services under the State.' This provision was added by the 77th Constitutional Amendment.
questions.landmark_case: General Constitutional Provision

questions.question: The 'creamy layer' concept in reservation policy was introduced in which case?

options.A: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
options.B: E.P. Royappa v. State of Tamil Nadu
options.C: Indra Sawhney v. Union of India

questions.explanation: The concept of 'creamy layer' was introduced by the Supreme Court in Indra Sawhney v. Union of India (1993). The court held that advanced sections or 'creamy layer' among the backward classes should not be eligible for reservation benefits. This ensures that reservation benefits reach the truly deserving and backward sections, while preventing undue benefit to those who have already achieved social and economic advancement.
questions.landmark_case: Indra Sawhney v. Union of India, 1993

questions.question: Which clause of Article 15 allows reservation in private educational institutions?
questions.explanation: Article 15(5) states that 'Nothing in this article or in sub-clause (g) of clause (1) of article 19 shall prevent the State from making any special provision, by law, for the advancement of any socially and educationally backward classes of citizens or for the Scheduled Castes or the Scheduled Tribes in so far as such special provisions relate to their admission to educational institutions including private educational institutions, whether aided or unaided by the State.' This was added by the 93rd Constitutional Amendment.
questions.landmark_case: General Constitutional Provision

questions.question: The principle of 'equal pay for equal work' is derived from:
questions.explanation: The principle of 'equal pay for equal work' is derived from Article 39(d) of the Directive Principles of State Policy, which states that the State shall secure for men and women equal right to an adequate means of livelihood. While Article 16 provides for equality of opportunity in public employment, the specific doctrine of 'equal pay for equal work' stems from Article 39(d).
questions.landmark_case: General Constitutional Principle

questions.question: Which case established the relationship between Article 14 and right to education?

options.A: Mohan Kumar v. Union of India
options.B: Unni Krishnan v. State of Andhra Pradesh

questions.explanation: In Unni Krishnan v. State of Andhra Pradesh (1993), the Supreme Court held that the right to education flows from Article 21 and is part of the right to life and dignity. The court also held that Article 14's guarantee of equality extends to educational opportunities. This case laid the foundation for the later constitutional amendment (Article 21A) making education a fundamental right.
questions.landmark_case: Unni Krishnan v. State of Andhra Pradesh, 1993

question: Article 19(1)(a) of the Indian Constitution guarantees the right to:
explanation: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees to all citizens the right to freedom of speech and expression. This includes the freedom to express thoughts, opinions, and ideas through speech, writing, printing, painting, or any other manner. The Supreme Court has interpreted this broadly to include the right to receive and disseminate information, freedom of the press, and the right to express dissent.
landmark_case: Bennett Coleman & Co. v. Union of India, 1972

question: Which right is protected under Article 19(1)(b)?

options.B: Right to assemble peaceably and without arms
options.C: Right to form associations or unions
options.D: Right to move freely throughout the territory of India

explanation: Article 19(1)(b) guarantees to all citizens the right to assemble peaceably and without arms. This right is essential for democratic participation and includes the right to hold meetings, processions, and demonstrations. However, it is subject to reasonable restrictions in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India or public order.

question: The right to form trade unions is protected under which sub-clause of Article 19?
explanation: Article 19(1)(c) guarantees to all citizens the right to form associations or unions, which includes the right to form trade unions. The Supreme Court has consistently held that the right to form trade unions is a fundamental right essential for workers to collectively bargain and protect their interests. However, this right can be restricted for members of armed forces and paramilitary forces.
landmark_case: All India Bank Employees' Association v. National Industrial Tribunal, 1961

question: Article 19(1)(d) guarantees the right to:

options.B: Move freely throughout the territory of India
options.C: Reside and settle in any part of the country

explanation: Article 19(1)(d) guarantees to all citizens the right to move freely throughout the territory of India. This right includes the freedom to travel and move from one place to another within the country. The Supreme Court has held that this right is fundamental to the concept of citizenship and unity of the nation.

question: Which of the following restrictions can be imposed on the right to freedom of speech under Article 19(2)?

options.A: In the interest of national security
options.B: In the interest of friendly relations with foreign nations
options.C: In the interest of public order

explanation: Article 19(2) allows reasonable restrictions on the right to freedom of speech and expression in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence. These restrictions must be reasonable and not arbitrary.

question: Article 20(1) protects against:
explanation: Article 20(1) states that no person shall be convicted of any offence except for violation of a law in force at the time of the commission of the act charged as an offence, nor be subjected to a penalty greater than that which might have been inflicted under the law in force at the time of the commission of the offence. This protects against ex post facto (retroactive) criminal laws.

question: The protection against double jeopardy is provided by:
explanation: Article 20(2) states that no person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once. This is the constitutional guarantee against double jeopardy, based on the legal maxim 'nemo debet bis vexari pro una et eadem causa' (no person should be twice vexed for the same cause). This principle ensures that criminal prosecution and punishment should be a single event.

question: The right against self-incrimination is guaranteed by:
explanation: Article 20(3) states that no person accused of any offence shall be compelled to be a witness against himself. This embodies the right against self-incrimination, which is a fundamental principle of criminal law. The Supreme Court has extended this protection to include not only oral testimony but also the production of documents and other material evidence.
landmark_case: M.H. Hoskot v. State of Maharashtra, 1978

question: Article 21 guarantees the right to:
explanation: Article 21 states that no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law. This article has been interpreted expansively by the Supreme Court to include various facets of dignified life such as the right to livelihood, right to privacy, right to education, and many other rights essential for human dignity.

question: Which case established that the right to life includes the right to livelihood?

options.A: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
options.B: Francis Coralie Mullin v. Union of India
options.C: Olga Tellis v. Bombay Municipal Corporation

explanation: In Olga Tellis v. Bombay Municipal Corporation (1985), the Supreme Court held that the right to life under Article 21 includes the right to livelihood. The court stated that if a person is deprived of his livelihood, he is deprived of his life. This case involved the eviction of pavement dwellers and established that the government cannot arbitrarily remove people without providing alternative livelihood arrangements.
landmark_case: Olga Tellis v. Bombay Municipal Corporation, 1985

question: Article 21A was added to the Constitution by which amendment?
explanation: Article 21A was added to the Constitution by the 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002. This article makes free and compulsory education for children in the age group of 6 to 14 years a fundamental right. The amendment also directed the State to provide such education in such manner as the State may, by law, determine.

question: Article 22 provides protection against arrest and detention. According to Article 22(1), an arrested person:

options.A: Must be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours
options.B: Cannot be denied the right to consult a legal practitioner of his choice
options.C: Cannot be detained for more than 24 hours without being informed of the grounds
options.D: Can be detained without any formal charges

explanation: Article 22(1) states that no person who is arrested shall be detained in custody without being informed, as soon as may be, of the grounds for such arrest nor shall he be denied the right to consult, and to be defended by, a legal practitioner of his choice. This is a fundamental procedural safeguard against arbitrary arrest.

question: According to Article 22(2), an arrested person must be produced before a magistrate within:
explanation: Article 22(2) states that every person who is arrested and detained in custody shall be produced before the nearest magistrate within a period of twenty-four hours of such arrest, excluding the time necessary for the journey from the place of arrest to the court of the magistrate. This ensures judicial oversight of police detention.

question: The protections under Article 22(1) and 22(2) do not apply to:

options.C: Enemy aliens and persons under preventive detention

explanation: Article 22(3) explicitly states that nothing in clauses (1) and (2) shall apply to any person who for the time being is an enemy alien or to any person who is arrested or detained under any law providing for preventive detention. This acknowledges the special nature of wartime detention and preventive detention laws.

question: Preventive detention means detention:

options.B: Without trial to prevent commission of a crime
options.C: As punishment for a minor offense
options.D: For default in payment of fine

explanation: Preventive detention is detention without trial to prevent an individual from committing a crime in the future. Unlike punitive detention (which comes after conviction), preventive detention is based on suspicion that the person might commit a crime. This is allowed under Article 22(3)(b) and is governed by preventive detention laws.

question: Which restriction can be imposed on the right to assemble peacefully under Article 19(1)(b)?

options.A: In the interest of decency or morality
options.B: In the interest of sovereignty and integrity of India or public order
options.C: In the interest of friendly relations with foreign States
options.D: In the interest of national security

explanation: Article 19(3) allows reasonable restrictions on the right to assemble peaceably and without arms in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India or public order. The restrictions must be reasonable and not arbitrary. The Supreme Court has held that public order means preservation of public peace and tranquility.
landmark_case: Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar, 1966

question: The right to practice any profession, trade, or business is guaranteed under:
explanation: Article 19(1)(g) guarantees to all citizens the right to practise any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business. This right is subject to reasonable restrictions in the interests of the general public. The State can also impose requirements for professional or technical qualifications.
landmark_case: Dwijendra Prasad Sharma v. State of Uttar Pradesh, 1964

question: Article 19(6) allows the State to:
explanation: Article 19(6) explicitly states that nothing in sub-clause (g) shall affect the operation of any existing law in so far as it relates to the carrying on by the State, or by a corporation owned or controlled by the State, of any trade, business, industry or service, whether to the exclusion, complete or partial, of citizens or otherwise. This allows State monopolies.

question: Which case established that the right to life includes the right to privacy?

options.A: R. Rajagopal v. State of Tamil Nadu
options.B: K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India

explanation: In K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India (2017), the Supreme Court by a unanimous 9-judge bench overruled earlier precedents and held that the right to privacy is a fundamental right emerging from Articles 19 and 21 of the Constitution. The court stated that privacy is intrinsic to the right to life and personal liberty.
landmark_case: K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India, 2017

question: The concept of 'procedural due process' in Article 21 was established in:

options.A: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
options.B: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
options.C: Francis Coralie Mullin v. Union of India

explanation: In Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978), the Supreme Court introduced the concept of 'procedural due process' in Article 21. The court held that the procedure established by law must be 'right, just and fair' and not arbitrary, fanciful or oppressive. This decision significantly expanded the scope of Article 21.
landmark_case: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India, 1978

question: The concept of 'time, place and manner' restrictions on freedom of speech was established in:

options.A: Bennett Coleman & Co. v. Union of India
options.B: R. Rajagopal v. State of Tamil Nadu
options.C: Sakal Papers v. Union of India
options.D: Bennett Coleman & Co. v. Union of India

explanation: In Sakal Papers v. Union of India (1962), the Supreme Court held that the government cannot regulate the newspaper industry by imposing restrictions that affect the fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression. The court established the principle that any restriction must be reasonable and in public interest, not arbitrary.
landmark_case: Sakal Papers v. Union of India, 1962

question: The right to receive information is part of which fundamental right?
explanation: The Supreme Court has consistently held that the right to receive information is an integral part of the freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a). In Secretary, Ministry of Information v. Cricket Association of Bengal (1995), the court held that the right to know is derived from the right to free speech and expression.
landmark_case: Secretary, Ministry of Information v. Cricket Association of Bengal, 1995

question: The Supreme Court has held that sedition laws under Section 124A IPC must be interpreted narrowly. This principle was established in:

options.A: Balwant Singh v. State of Punjab
options.B: Sedar Singh v. State of Uttar Pradesh
options.D: Kanhaiya Kumar v. State (NCT of Delhi)

explanation: In Balwant Singh v. State of Punjab (1995), the Supreme Court held that mere raising of slogans like 'Khalistan Zindabad' without any threat or call for violence, and not in a manner that causes public disorder, would not constitute sedition. The court emphasized that sedition requires intention or tendency to create disorder or disturbance of public peace by resort to violence.
landmark_case: Balwant Singh v. State of Punjab, 1995

question: The right to form associations includes the right to:
explanation: The Supreme Court has held that the right to form associations under Article 19(1)(c) necessarily includes the right not to associate and the right to dissociate. In Hilda Mary Bates v. State (1995), the court held that forcing someone to continue association against their will violates the freedom of association.

question: The right to residence and settle under Article 19(1)(e) is subject to restrictions for:
explanation: Article 19(5) allows reasonable restrictions on the rights under sub-clauses (d) and (e) either in the interests of the general public or for the protection of the interests of any Scheduled Tribe. These restrictions must be reasonable and in the public interest.

question: Article 23 of the Indian Constitution prohibits:

options.C: Both traffic in human beings and begar

explanation: Article 23(1) explicitly states that 'Traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour are prohibited, and any contravention of this provision shall be an offence punishable in accordance with law.' This article aims to protect individuals from exploitation and various forms of forced labour including trafficking for illegal and immoral purposes.

question: Begar refers to:
explanation: Begar is defined as forced labour without payment. The term has been interpreted to include any form of forced labour, whether paid or unpaid, where the person is compelled to work against their will. The Supreme Court has held that begar includes various forms of forced labour and exploitation, making the scope very broad.

question: Article 23(2) allows the State to impose:

options.B: Compulsory service for public purposes without discrimination

explanation: Article 23(2) states that 'Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from imposing compulsory service for public purposes, and in imposing such service the State shall not make any discrimination on grounds only of religion, race, caste or class or any of them.' This allows for legitimate compulsory services like military service, jury duty, etc.

question: Article 24 prohibits employment of children below the age of:

options.B: 14 years in any factory, mine, or hazardous employment

explanation: Article 24 explicitly states that 'No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.' This is an absolute prohibition in hazardous employment, with no exceptions mentioned in the Constitution.

question: The Factories Act of 1948 sets the minimum age for child employment in factories at:
explanation: The Factories Act of 1948 was the first post-independence act setting the minimum age for child employment in factories at 14 years. This aligned with the constitutional mandate under Article 24, which prohibits employment of children below 14 years in factories, mines, or other hazardous employment.

question: The Mines Act of 1952 prohibits employment of persons under the age of:
explanation: The Mines Act of 1952 prohibits employment of persons under 18 years in mines. This is stricter than Article 24's general prohibition and reflects the hazardous nature of mining work. The act was designed to ensure the safety and protection of young workers in the mining industry.

question: The Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act of 1986 defines a 'child' as a person who has not completed:
explanation: The Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986 defined 'child' as a person who has not completed 14th year of age. This aligned with Article 24's constitutional prohibition. However, the 2016 amendment made the prohibition absolute, completely forbidding employment of children below 14 years.

question: The Child Labour (Prohibition & Regulation) Amendment Act of 2016:

options.A: Completely forbids employment of children below 14 years
options.B: Bans employment of adolescents (14-18) in hazardous occupations

explanation: The 2016 Amendment Act: (1) Completely forbids employment of children below 14 years of age in any form of work; (2) Bans employment of people between 14 and 18 years in hazardous occupations and processes; (3) Made punishments for violators stricter; (4) Allows children to be employed in certain family occupations and as artists under regulated conditions.

question: Bonded labour system is unconstitutional under:
explanation: The Supreme Court has interpreted Article 23 to prohibit bonded labour system, where a person is forced to work against an unrepaid loan or debt. In cases like People's Union for Democratic Rights v. Union of India (1982), the court held that bonded labour violates Article 23 and the State has a duty to eradicate this practice.
landmark_case: People's Union for Democratic Rights v. Union of India, 1982

question: The Bonded Labour System (Abolition) Act was enacted in:
explanation: The Bonded Labour System (Abolition) Act, 1976 was enacted to give effect to Article 23's prohibition of forced labour. The act declares the bonded labour system to be unlawful and provides for the abolition of the system and for the release and rehabilitation of bonded labourers.

question: Human trafficking for prostitution is prohibited under:
explanation: Article 23 explicitly prohibits 'traffic in human beings' which includes buying and selling men and women for illegal and immoral activities like prostitution. This has been interpreted to include human trafficking for sexual exploitation, forced labour, and other forms of exploitation.

question: The Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act was enacted in:
explanation: The Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956 (now known as the Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act, 1986) was enacted to combat the social evil of prostitution and trafficking of women and girls. This act gives effect to Article 23's prohibition of traffic in human beings.
landmark_case: Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956

question: Article 23 protects citizens against exploitation by:
explanation: Article 23 protects citizens against exploitation both by the State and private individuals. The prohibition against traffic in human beings and forced labour applies regardless of who is committing the exploitation. The State has a duty to protect citizens from these evils through punitive action and positive measures.

question: Employment of children in non-hazardous work is:

options.B: Allowed under Article 24 subject to regulation

explanation: Article 24 absolutely prohibits employment of children below 14 years only in 'any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.' Employment in non-hazardous work is not prohibited by Article 24 and may be regulated by other laws. However, recent amendments have made the prohibition more comprehensive.

question: The term 'forced labour' under Article 23 includes:

options.B: Only labour under threat of physical harm
options.C: Any labour exacted under coercion, threat, or menace

explanation: The Supreme Court has broadly interpreted 'forced labour' under Article 23 to include any labour exacted under coercion, threat, or menace of penalty. This includes not just physical force but also psychological compulsion, economic duress, and other forms of coercion that deprive a person of free choice.
landmark_case: J. Jayaprakash Narayan v. State of Karnataka, 1995

question: The Child Labour (Prohibition & Regulation) Amendment Rules of 2017 provide for:

options.A: Prevention, prohibition, rescue, and rehabilitation framework
options.B: Only working hours and conditions for artists

explanation: The 2017 Amendment Rules provide: (1) A framework for prevention, prohibition, rescue, and rehabilitation of child and adolescent workers; (2) Clarification concerning employment in family enterprises; (3) Provides safeguards for artists, specifying working hours and conditions. This comprehensive framework ensures the effective implementation of child labour laws.

question: Article 35 of the Constitution empowers Parliament to:

options.A: Make laws prescribing punishment for acts prohibited by Article 23

explanation: Article 35 states that 'Parliament shall have, and the Legislature of a State shall not have, power to make laws... for prescribing punishment for those acts which are declared to be offences under this Part.' This includes making laws to punish acts prohibited under Article 23, ensuring uniform national legislation.

question: The practice of 'Devadasi system' violates which fundamental right?
explanation: The Devadasi system, where young girls are dedicated to temples and later exploited, violates Article 23 as it involves forced labour and often trafficking in human beings. The Supreme Court has consistently held that such practices are unconstitutional and the State has a duty to eradicate them.

question: Employment of children in family business:

options.C: Is allowed under specific conditions and safeguards
options.D: Is prohibited only in urban areas

explanation: The Child Labour Amendment Act of 2016 allows children to be employed in certain family occupations and as artists, but under specific conditions and safeguards. The 2017 rules provide detailed framework for working hours and conditions to ensure the employment does not affect the child's education or development.

question: The National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) was enacted to:

options.B: Ensure at least 100 days of guaranteed wage employment

explanation: MGNREGA was enacted to provide at least 100 days of guaranteed wage employment to rural households and to prevent forced labour by providing alternative livelihood opportunities. The Act aims to give effect to the constitutional mandate of Article 23 by providing alternative sources of livelihood.
landmark_case: Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, 2005

question: Payment of wages less than the minimum wage constitutes:
explanation: The Supreme Court in Deena v. Union of India (1983) held that payment of wages less than the minimum wage constitutes forced labour under Article 23. The court stated that if a person is compelled to work for inadequate wages, it amounts to forced labour and violates the prohibition under Article 23.

question: The original Factories Act prohibited employment of children at night in:
explanation: The 1954 amendment to the Factories Act prohibited children below 17 years from being employed at night in factories. This amendment reflected the understanding that night work was particularly harmful to the health and development of young workers.

question: Slavery is implicitly banned by which article?
explanation: While slavery is not explicitly mentioned, Article 23 implicitly bans slavery through its prohibition of 'traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour.' The term 'traffic' is comprehensive enough to cover slavery, which involves complete subjugation and exploitation of human beings.

question: The State must protect citizens from exploitation through:

options.C: Both punitive action and positive measures

explanation: Article 23 protects citizens against exploitation by both the State and private individuals. The State has a dual duty: (1) punitive action against those who violate the prohibition; and (2) positive measures to protect citizens from exploitation, including providing alternative livelihood opportunities and rehabilitation.

question: The 2016 Child Labour Amendment increased the number of prohibited occupations from:

options.A: 13 occupations and 57 processes to complete prohibition
options.B: 10 occupations and 40 processes to 15 occupations and 60 processes
options.C: 15 occupations and 50 processes to 13 occupations and 57 processes
options.D: 12 occupations and 55 processes to 14 occupations and 58 processes

explanation: The original Child Labour Act prohibited employment of children in 13 occupations and 57 processes. The 2016 Amendment Act completely forbids employment of children below 14 years of age, eliminating the earlier distinction between hazardous and non-hazardous occupations and processes.

question: Article 25 guarantees freedom of conscience and the right to:
explanation: Article 25(1) states that 'Subject to public order, morality and health and to the other provisions of this Part, all persons are equally entitled to freedom of conscience and the right freely to profess, practise and propagate religion.' This is one of the most comprehensive provisions for religious freedom in the world.

question: The wearing and carrying of kirpans is included in the profession of the:
explanation: Explanation I to Article 25 states that 'The wearing and carrying of kirpans shall be deemed to be included in the profession of the Sikh religion.' This explicit protection was included to safeguard the religious identity and practices of Sikh citizens.

question: The term 'Hindu' in Article 25(2)(b) includes:

options.B: Followers of Hindu, Sikh, Jaina or Buddhist religion

explanation: Explanation II to Article 25 states that 'In sub-clause (b) of clause (2), the reference to Hindus shall be construed as including a reference to persons professing the Sikh, Jaina or Buddhist religion, and the reference to Hindu religious institutions shall be construed accordingly.' This ensures inclusive interpretation.

question: Article 25(2)(a) allows the State to:

options.B: Regulate or restrict economic, financial, political or other secular activities associated with religious practice

explanation: Article 25(2)(a) states that the State may regulate or restrict any economic, financial, political or other secular activity which may be associated with religious practice. This allows the State to maintain secular governance while respecting religious freedom.

question: The essential religious practices doctrine was established in:

options.A: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Shri Lakshmindar Tirtha Swamiyar of Shri Shirur Mutt
options.B: Mohd. Hanif Quareshi v. the State of Bihar
options.C: Durgah Committee, Ajmer v. Syed Hussain Ali

explanation: The essential religious practices doctrine was developed through multiple cases including: Shirur Mutt case (1954) - protected rituals integral to religion; Hanif Qureshi case (1958) - held cow sacrifice not essential to Islam; Durgah Committee case (1961) - only essential religious practices receive constitutional protection.
landmark_case: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Shri Lakshmindar Tirtha Swamiyar of Shri Shirur Mutt, 1954

question: In the Shirur Mutt case, the Supreme Court held that:

options.A: Only essential religious practices receive protection
options.B: All religious practices must be followed
options.C: State can control all religious institutions

explanation: In Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Shri Lakshmindar Tirtha Swamiyar of Shri Shirur Mutt (1954), the Supreme Court held that only essential religious practices receive constitutional protection. The court stated that 'it is for the courts to determine in each case what are integral essentials of a religion.'
landmark_case: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Shri Lakshmindar Tirtha Swamiyar of Shri Shirur Mutt, 1954

question: The case that held cow sacrifice on Bakr-Eid is not an essential part of Islam was:

options.B: Mohd. Hanif Quareshi v. the State of Bihar

explanation: In Mohd. Hanif Quareshi v. the State of Bihar (1958), the Supreme Court held that cow sacrifice on Bakr-Eid was not an essential part of Islam and could be prohibited by the State under Article 25(2)(a) in the interest of public order and morality.
landmark_case: Mohd. Hanif Quareshi v. the State of Bihar, 1958

question: Article 25(2)(b) allows the State to make laws for:

options.C: Social welfare and reform or throwing open Hindu religious institutions to all classes

explanation: Article 25(2)(b) allows the State to make laws providing for social welfare and reform or the throwing open of Hindu religious institutions of a public character to all classes and sections of Hindus. This enables the State to eliminate caste-based discrimination in religious institutions.

question: Article 26 guarantees to religious denominations the right to:

options.A: Establish and maintain institutions for religious purposes only
options.C: Establish institutions, manage religious affairs, own property and administer it

explanation: Article 26 states that every religious denomination has the right: (a) to establish and maintain institutions for religious and charitable purposes; (b) to manage its own affairs in matters of religion; (c) to own and acquire movable and immovable property; and (d) to administer such property in accordance with law.

question: The term 'religious denomination' means:

options.A: Only major religions like Hinduism, Islam, Christianity
options.B: Any group of persons having a common religious faith and religious name

explanation: A 'religious denomination' has been defined by courts as a group of persons having a common religious faith and religious name, and common religious activities. This includes various sects and sub-groups within religions, ensuring broader protection of religious autonomy.

question: Article 27 prohibits:

options.B: Compulsion to pay taxes specifically appropriated for promotion of a particular religion

explanation: Article 27 states that 'No person shall be compelled to pay any taxes, the proceeds of which are specifically appropriated in payment of expenses for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion or religious denomination.' This ensures secular funding of the State.

question: Article 28(1) prohibits:

options.A: Religious instruction in all educational institutions
options.B: Religious instruction in educational institutions wholly maintained out of State funds

explanation: Article 28(1) states that 'No religious instruction shall be provided in any educational institution wholly maintained out of State funds.' This ensures secular education in State-funded institutions, while allowing religious instruction in private institutions.

question: Article 28(3) requires consent for religious instruction in:

options.B: State-recognized institutions or institutions receiving State aid

explanation: Article 28(3) states that 'No person attending any educational institution recognised by the State or receiving aid out of State funds shall be required to take part in any religious instruction or religious worship without consent.' This provides safeguards for students in State-recognized or aided institutions.

question: The case involving Tandava dance by Ananda Margis was:
explanation: In Acharya Jagdishwaranand Avadhuta v. Commissioner of Police, Calcutta (1984), the Supreme Court held that Tandava dance in public places with lethal weapons and human skulls by Ananda Margis is not an essential religious rite, and prohibition in interest of public order and morality is not a violation of Articles 25 and 26.
landmark_case: Acharya Jagdishwaranand Avadhuta v. Commissioner of Police, Calcutta, 1984

question: The Bijoe Emmanuel case involved the right to:

options.A: Refuse to sing national anthem due to religious beliefs

explanation: In Bijoe Emmanuel v. State of Kerala (1987), the Supreme Court held that expulsion of students for abstaining from singing the national anthem due to religious beliefs violated fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(a) (freedom of speech and expression) and 25 (freedom of religion), emphasizing religious freedom as a constitutional tenet.
landmark_case: Bijoe Emmanuel v. State of Kerala, 1987

question: The case that held mosques are not essential for religious practice was:
explanation: In Dr. M. Ismail Faruqui v. Union of India (1994), the Supreme Court held that mosques, temples, and churches are immovable properties not required for religious practice under Article 26. Thus, the State may acquire them under eminent domain without violating religious freedom.
landmark_case: Dr. M. Ismail Faruqui v. Union of India, 1994

question: The Sabarimala Temple case challenged restrictions on:

options.B: Women of 'menstruating years' from entering Sabarimala Temple

explanation: In Indian Young Lawyers' Association v. State of Kerala (2018), the Supreme Court by 4:1 majority declared the Sabarimala Temple's custom prohibiting women of 'menstruating years' from entering the temple premises unconstitutional, implying a violation of equality principles under Article 14.
landmark_case: Indian Young Lawyers' Association v. State of Kerala, 2018

question: The right to freedom of religion is subject to restrictions based on:

options.A: Public order, morality, and health only
options.B: Other provisions of Part III of the Constitution
options.C: Both public order, morality, health and other provisions of Part III

explanation: Article 25 is explicitly subject to 'public order, morality and health and to the other provisions of this Part.' This means religious freedom can be restricted to maintain public order, morality, health, and to protect other fundamental rights.

question: The right to manage affairs in matters of religion includes:
explanation: Article 26(b) guarantees the right to manage its own affairs in matters of religion. This includes determining essential religious practices, managing internal administration, deciding on theological matters, and other aspects of religious governance without State interference.

question: Article 27 ensures:

options.A: No State funding for religious institutions
options.B: No compulsion to pay taxes for promotion of a particular religion

explanation: Article 27 prohibits compulsion to pay taxes specifically appropriated for promotion or maintenance of a particular religion. This ensures that religious institutions are not funded through compulsory taxes, maintaining secular governance while respecting religious freedom.

question: Article 28(2) applies to institutions:

options.B: State-administered but established under endowment or trust

explanation: Article 28(2) states that nothing in clause (1) shall apply to an educational institution which is administered by the State but has been established under any endowment or trust which requires that religious instruction shall be imparted in such institution.

question: The right to propagate religion means:

options.B: Attempting to persuade others to accept one's faith

explanation: The right to propagate religion under Article 25 means the right to attempt to persuade others to accept one's faith through peaceful means, not through force or coercion. It includes the right to spread religious beliefs and teachings through legitimate means.

question: The State can interfere in religious affairs when:

options.A: Religious practices violate public order, morality, or health
options.C: Religious leaders disagree with government policies
options.D: Religious practices are followed by minorities

explanation: Article 26 is subject to public order, morality, and health. The State can interfere in religious affairs when religious practices violate these constitutional limits. However, the State cannot interfere in purely religious matters that do not affect public welfare.

question: The concept of 'secular activity associated with religious practice' allows State regulation of:

options.C: Economic, financial, political or other secular activities associated with religious practice

explanation: Article 25(2)(a) allows the State to regulate or restrict economic, financial, political or other secular activities which may be associated with religious practice. This enables the State to maintain secular governance while respecting religious freedom.

question: For minors, consent for religious instruction under Article 28(3) is given by:
explanation: Article 28(3) explicitly states that 'unless such person or, if such person is a minor, his guardian has given his consent thereto.' This provision ensures that minors are not compelled to participate in religious activities without their guardian's consent.

question: Article 29(1) protects the right of any section of citizens having a distinct language, script or culture to:
explanation: Article 29(1) states that 'Any section of the citizens residing in the territory of India or any part thereof having a distinct language, script or culture of its own shall have the right to conserve the same.' This is available to any section of citizens, not just minorities.

question: Article 29(2) guarantees that no citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds of:

options.C: Religion, race, caste, language or any of them

explanation: Article 29(2) explicitly states that 'No citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.' This ensures non-discrimination in State and aided institutions.

question: Article 30(1) guarantees to minorities the right to:

options.B: Establish and administer educational institutions of their choice
options.D: Be exempt from national education policy

explanation: Article 30(1) states that 'All minorities, whether based on religion or language, shall have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.' This is a special right for minorities to maintain their distinct identity through education.

question: Article 30(1A) was added by which amendment?
explanation: Article 30(1A) was added by the 51st Amendment of 1984. It states that when making any law for compulsory acquisition of property of a minority educational institution, the State shall ensure that the compensation fixed does not restrict or abrogate the right under Article 30(1).

question: Article 30(2) ensures that the State shall not discriminate against educational institutions on the ground that:

options.B: They are under the management of a minority
options.C: They are located in rural areas
options.D: They do not follow national curriculum

explanation: Article 30(2) states that 'The State shall not, in granting aid to educational institutions, discriminate against any educational institution on the ground that it is under the management of a minority, whether based on religion or language.' This ensures equal treatment in aid distribution.

question: The right under Article 29(1) to conserve language, script or culture is available to:

options.C: Any section of citizens with distinct language, script or culture

explanation: Article 29(1) uses the term 'any section of the citizens' not 'minority.' This means any group of citizens, whether majority or minority, having a distinct language, script or culture has the right to conserve the same. It applies to all citizens equally.

question: Minorities under Article 30 include:
explanation: Article 30 explicitly states that 'All minorities, whether based on religion or language, shall have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.' This covers both religious minorities (like Muslims, Christians, Sikhs) and linguistic minorities (like Tamilians, Bengalis in other states).

question: The case that established the test for classifying minority institutions was decided in:
explanation: In 2024, the Supreme Court of India clarified the test for classifying minority institutions under the constitutional equality provision. The court established guidelines to determine when an institution qualifies as a minority institution entitled to special protections under Article 30.
landmark_case: Supreme Court clarification on minority institutions classification, 2024

question: The right to conserve language, script or culture under Article 29(1) is:
explanation: Article 29(1) does not contain any restrictions or exceptions. It is an absolute right to conserve distinct language, script or culture. This ensures the preservation of cultural diversity and heritage in India.

question: The right to administer educational institutions under Article 30(1) includes:

options.C: Both establishing and administering, including appointments and curriculum

explanation: The right to administer includes the right to appoint teachers and staff, fix fees, frame curriculum, make rules for admission, discipline and other aspects of administration. This ensures autonomy of minority institutions in educational matters.

question: The State can acquire property of minority educational institutions:

options.B: With compensation that does not restrict or abrogate Article 30(1) rights
options.D: With consent of the institution only

explanation: Article 30(1A) requires that when acquiring property of minority educational institutions, the compensation must be such that it does not restrict or abrogate the right guaranteed under Article 30(1). This ensures fair compensation and protection of minority rights.

question: Article 29(2) applies to:
explanation: Article 29(2) explicitly applies to 'any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds.' This covers all institutions that receive State support, ensuring non-discrimination in admission policies.

question: The State discrimination against minority institutions in granting aid is prohibited by:
explanation: Article 30(2) specifically states that 'The State shall not, in granting aid to educational institutions, discriminate against any educational institution on the ground that it is under the management of a minority, whether based on religion or language.' This ensures equal treatment in aid distribution.

question: The protection under Article 29(1) is available to:
explanation: Article 29(1) specifically uses the term 'any section of the citizens' which means only citizens of India can claim this right. This distinguishes it from Article 25 which applies to 'all persons' including non-citizens.

question: The right under Article 30(1) to establish educational institutions:

options.C: Is subject to national education policy

explanation: Article 30(1) grants to minorities the absolute right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice. While institutions must comply with general laws, the core right to establish and maintain minority institutions is protected.

question: The case that upheld minority rights in education while ensuring national integration was:
explanation: The Supreme Court in these landmark cases (Ahmedabad St. Xavier's College v. State of Gujarat, T.M.A. Pai Foundation v. State of Karnataka, Islamic Academy of Education v. State of Karnataka) established the framework for balancing minority rights with national integration and educational standards.
landmark_case: Ahmedabad St. Xavier's College v. State of Gujarat, 1974

question: The relationship between Articles 29 and 30 was clarified in:
explanation: In 2002, the Supreme Court in the T.M.A. Pai Foundation case clarified the relationship between Articles 29 and 30, establishing that while Article 29 provides general cultural rights, Article 30 provides special rights to minorities for establishing and administering educational institutions.
landmark_case: T.M.A. Pai Foundation v. State of Karnataka, 2002

question: The concept of 'minority' for the purpose of Article 30 is determined by:

options.B: Both numerical strength and educational backwardness
options.C: Both numerical strength and religious identity

explanation: The Supreme Court in T.M.A. Pai Foundation case clarified that for determining minority status, both numerical strength and educational backwardness should be considered. A group that is numerically small but educationally advanced may not qualify as a minority under Article 30.
landmark_case: T.M.A. Pai Foundation v. State of Karnataka, 2002

question: The State can impose regulations on minority educational institutions to ensure:

options.C: Academic standards, transparency, and prevention of discrimination

explanation: While Article 30 guarantees the right to establish and administer educational institutions, the State can impose reasonable regulations to ensure academic standards, financial transparency, prevention of discrimination, and maintenance of educational quality, as long as these do not destroy the minority character.
landmark_case: Islamic Academy of Education v. State of Karnataka, 2003

question: The right to conserve language under Article 29(1):

options.B: Applies to any distinct language, script or culture

explanation: Article 29(1) uses the term 'distinct language, script or culture' which includes any language that has a distinct identity, not just scheduled or classical languages. This ensures protection of all cultural expressions and linguistic diversity.

question: The 93rd Amendment added Article 15(5) which allows:

options.A: Reservation in private unaided minority institutions
options.B: Reservation in private unaided non-minority institutions

explanation: The 93rd Amendment added Article 15(5) which allows the State to make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes or SCs/STs in admission to educational institutions including private unaided non-minority institutions.

question: Article 29(2) prohibits denial of admission on grounds of:

options.B: Race, caste, and place of birth only
options.C: Religion, race, caste, language or any of them

explanation: Article 29(2) explicitly prohibits denial of admission 'on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.' This comprehensive prohibition ensures equal access to educational opportunities in State and aided institutions.

question: The right to administer educational institutions under Article 30 includes the right to:

options.A: Set educational standards higher than State requirements
options.C: Appoint teachers and staff without any qualifications

explanation: The right to administer includes the right to set higher standards than the minimum requirements, maintain institutional autonomy, and ensure quality education. However, institutions cannot appoint unqualified teachers or charge excessive fees that make education inaccessible.

question: The distinction between Article 29(1) and Article 29(2) is:

options.A: Article 29(1) is for minorities only, Article 29(2) is for all citizens
options.B: Article 29(1) protects cultural rights, Article 29(2) ensures non-discrimination in education
options.C: Article 29(1) is absolute, Article 29(2) has exceptions

explanation: Article 29(1) uses 'any section of citizens' (broader than minorities) for cultural conservation, while Article 29(2) guarantees non-discrimination in education for all citizens. Both serve different but complementary purposes in protecting cultural diversity and educational equality.

question: The Supreme Court in 2024 clarified that for minority status, an institution must prove:

options.C: Minority character and effective control by the minority community

explanation: In the 2024 ruling, the Supreme Court clarified that for claiming minority status under Article 30, an institution must prove that it is established and administered by a minority community and that the community has effective control over its functioning, not just numerical minority.
landmark_case: Supreme Court 2024 ruling on minority institutions classification

question: Article 32 is described by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar as:

options.A: The heart and soul of the Constitution

explanation: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar famously described Article 32 as 'the heart and soul of the Constitution.' Article 32 guarantees the right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by Part III, making it the most important remedial provision.

question: Article 32(1) guarantees the right to move the Supreme Court for:

options.C: Review of any Supreme Court decision

explanation: Article 32(1) states that 'The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed.' This makes Article 32 itself a fundamental right.

question: Article 32(2) empowers the Supreme Court to issue:

options.B: Only writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari
options.C: Directions, orders or writs, whichever may be appropriate

explanation: Article 32(2) states that 'The Supreme Court shall have power to issue directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, whichever may be appropriate, for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by this Part.'

question: The five types of writs that can be issued under Article 32 are:

options.A: Habeas corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Quo warranto, Certiorari
options.B: Mandamus, Prohibition, Quo warranto, Certiorari, Review
options.C: Habeas corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Quo warranto, Appeal

explanation: Article 32(2) specifically mentions that the Supreme Court can issue writs in the nature of: (1) Habeas corpus, (2) Mandamus, (3) Prohibition, (4) Quo warranto, and (5) Certiorari. These are the five classical writs for enforcing fundamental rights.

question: Habeas corpus means:
explanation: Habeas corpus is a Latin term meaning 'you shall have the body.' It is a writ issued to produce a person who has been detained before the court to determine whether the detention is legal. It is used to secure the release of persons who have been unlawfully detained.

question: Mandamus means:
explanation: Mandamus is a Latin term meaning 'we command.' It is a writ issued by a court to direct a public authority to perform a public duty or to refrain from performing an act. It compels action when a legal duty exists but is not being performed.

question: Prohibition means:
explanation: Prohibition is a writ issued by a superior court to prevent an inferior court or tribunal from exceeding its jurisdiction or acting contrary to the rules of natural justice. It is issued when proceedings are about to be initiated or are pending but before the decision is rendered.

question: Quo warranto means:
explanation: Quo warranto is a Latin term meaning 'by what authority.' It is a writ issued to inquire into the legality of a claim or title to a public office. It is used to challenge the appointment or continuation of a person in a public office who is not legally entitled to hold it.

question: Certiorari means:
explanation: Certiorari is a Latin term meaning 'to certify' or 'to review.' It is a writ issued by a superior court to an inferior court or tribunal to transfer a case or to review its proceedings. It is used to quash orders that are ultra vires or passed without jurisdiction.

question: Article 32(3) allows Parliament to:

options.B: Empower any other court to exercise powers of the Supreme Court under Article 32(2)
options.D: Transfer all writ cases to High Courts

explanation: Article 32(3) states that 'Without prejudice to the powers conferred on the Supreme Court by clauses (1) and (2), Parliament may by law empower any other court to exercise within the local limits of its jurisdiction all or any of the powers exercisable by the Supreme Court under clause (2).' This extends writ jurisdiction to other courts.

question: Article 32(4) states that the right guaranteed by Article 32:

options.A: Can be suspended by the President
options.C: Shall not be suspended except as otherwise provided by this Constitution
options.D: Can be suspended during martial law

explanation: Article 32(4) states that 'The right guaranteed by this article shall not be suspended except as otherwise provided for by this Constitution.' This ensures that fundamental right to constitutional remedies cannot be arbitrarily suspended.

question: The writ of habeas corpus is used to:

options.A: Compel performance of a public duty
options.B: Release a person from unlawful detention
options.C: Prevent an inferior court from acting
options.D: Challenge the authority of a public office holder

explanation: The writ of habeas corpus is used to secure the release of a person who has been unlawfully detained. When a person is arrested without legal authority or is detained beyond the period allowed by law, the court can issue this writ to produce the detained person and determine the legality of the detention.

question: The writ of mandamus is used to:

options.A: Release a person from unlawful detention
options.B: Compel performance of a public duty
options.C: Prevent an inferior court from acting
options.D: Challenge the authority of a public office holder

explanation: The writ of mandamus is used to compel a public authority to perform a duty that it is legally required to perform. This writ is issued when a public official fails to act according to law, despite having a clear legal obligation to do so.

question: The writ of prohibition is used to:

options.A: Release a person from unlawful detention
options.B: Compel performance of a public duty
options.C: Prevent an inferior court or tribunal from acting
options.D: Challenge the authority of a public office holder

explanation: The writ of prohibition is issued by a superior court to prevent an inferior court or tribunal from exceeding its jurisdiction or acting contrary to the rules of natural justice. It is issued when proceedings are about to be initiated or are pending.

question: The writ of quo warranto is used to:

options.A: Release a person from unlawful detention
options.B: Compel performance of a public duty
options.C: Prevent an inferior court from acting
options.D: Challenge the right of a person to hold a public office

explanation: The writ of quo warranto is used to inquire into the legal authority by which a public office is held. It is issued to challenge the appointment or continuation of a person in a public office who is not legally entitled to hold it.

question: The writ of certiorari is used to:

options.A: Release a person from unlawful detention
options.B: Compel performance of a public duty
options.C: Prevent an inferior court from acting
options.D: Quash the orders of an inferior court

explanation: The writ of certiorari is used by a superior court to quash or set aside the orders of an inferior court or tribunal that are ultra vires or passed without jurisdiction. It can also be used to transfer a case from an inferior court.

question: The Basic Structure doctrine was established in:

options.B: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
options.C: Minerva Mills v. Union of India
options.D: Waman Rao v. Union of India

explanation: The Basic Structure doctrine was established in Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973). The Supreme Court held that Parliament cannot amend the Constitution to destroy its basic features. This doctrine ensures that fundamental rights and the constitutional structure cannot be destroyed by amendments.
landmark_case: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala, 1973

question: The Maneka Gandhi case was filed under:

options.C: Article 32 challenging violation of Articles 14, 19, and 21

explanation: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978) was filed under Article 32 challenging the impounding of her passport. The Supreme Court held that this violated her fundamental rights under Articles 14, 19, and 21, establishing the 'triumvirate' test and expanding the scope of Article 21.

question: The difference between Article 32 and Article 226 is:

options.A: Article 32 is a fundamental right, Article 226 is a constitutional right
options.B: Article 32 can be issued only by Supreme Court, Article 226 by High Courts
options.C: Article 32 is for fundamental rights only, Article 226 is for both fundamental and other legal rights

explanation: Key differences: (1) Article 32 is a fundamental right while Article 226 is a constitutional right; (2) Article 32 jurisdiction is in Supreme Court while Article 226 is in High Courts; (3) Article 32 is for enforcement of fundamental rights while Article 226 has wider scope covering both fundamental and other legal rights.

question: Any person whose fundamental right is violated can approach:

options.C: Both Supreme Court and High Courts

explanation: Under Article 32, any person can approach the Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamental rights. Under Article 226, any person can approach the High Courts for enforcement of fundamental rights as well as other legal rights. This provides multiple avenues for constitutional remedies.

question: The writ jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under Article 32 is:
explanation: The writ jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under Article 32 is original jurisdiction. This means that persons can directly approach the Supreme Court without going through lower courts first, emphasizing the importance of fundamental rights enforcement.

question: The principle of 'locus standi' in Article 32 cases means:

options.A: Only the affected person can file the petition
options.B: Any person with sufficient interest can file the petition
options.C: Only lawyers can file the petition
options.D: Only the Advocate General can file the petition

explanation: The principle of 'locus standi' in Article 32 cases has been expanded by the Supreme Court. While traditionally only the affected person could file, now any person with sufficient interest in protecting fundamental rights can file a petition, including public interest litigants.

question: The Supreme Court can issue writs:

options.C: Against any 'State' as defined under Article 12

explanation: Article 32 allows the Supreme Court to issue writs against any 'State' as defined under Article 12, which includes the Government and Parliament of India, Governments and Legislatures of States, and all local or other authorities under the control of the Government of India.

question: The concept of 'continuing mandamus' was developed to:

options.B: Ensure continued compliance with court orders over time
options.D: Transfer cases from one court to another

explanation: The concept of 'continuing mandamus' was developed by the Supreme Court to ensure continued compliance with court orders over time. It is used when a one-time direction is insufficient and continuous monitoring is needed to ensure effective implementation of fundamental rights.

question: Article 32 cannot be suspended except:

options.C: As otherwise provided by the Constitution

explanation: Article 32(4) explicitly states that 'The right guaranteed by this article shall not be suspended except as otherwise provided for by this Constitution.' Even during emergencies, the Constitution does not generally suspend the right to constitutional remedies, emphasizing its fundamental nature.
